texts.definition: Gameplay situations where a player cannot win but can decide which other player should.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay situations where a player cannot win but can decide which other player should.</style>

Games provide players with possibilities to do actions that can influence their own and other players' positions in the game state. While players typically try to improve their own situations — otherwise they are arguable not gaming — this is not always possible. Something players can perform actions but only positively affect the situations of other players. Taken to the extreme, this can allow, or force, a player to make an action that determines who will win a game as long as it isn't the player itself. Such players are <style="CurrentLink">Kingmakers</style>.
Wikipedia has a page on the same concept under the name [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingmaker_scenario Kingmaker Scenario].

<style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> is very rarely intentionally designed to be present in most game instances of a game, but can occur in many games anyway. Wikipedia lists the television series Survivor as an example where <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> situations are explicitly designed for.

The possibility of <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> situation in games are in many cases unwanted so it is usually a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Negative%20Patterns">Negative Pattern</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> typically occurs in the <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> of a game since this is when positions are more or less established. The typical causes for it to occur are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Strategies">Dominant Strategies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="early-leaving-players">Early Leaving Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="possibility-graceful-surrender">Possibility of Graceful Surrender</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-game-states">Unwinnable Game States</link></style> so one strategy to avoid <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> possibilities is to avoid those patterns.

If the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> situations have been observed in a game, there are some design features that can work against it occurring. <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style> works against <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> or a <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style> making a <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> emerge. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> can make players not realize that there actually exists a <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> situation; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> often do this by having at least some of the <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> be hidden (see for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lords%20of%20Waterdeep">Lords of Waterdeep</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ticket%20to%20Ride">Ticket to Ride</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Village">Village</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> can also be mitigated by <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> (which can trick players into believing they have a chance to win and thereby not engage in kingmaking. It can also be mitigated by giving players <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> for their gameplay so they don't end or unbalance game instances just because they themselves cannot win. <style="Link"><link="revoke-rules">Revoke Rules</link></style> can offer a less bad option in <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> situations by letting players suffer a penalty for a violation of the rules but without necessarily losing the game.

<style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> typically occurs in the <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> when players' positions tend to rather clearly established. This makes the number of candidates for winning narrower and in this sense <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> can help players perceive a <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style>. Just as <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> can work against <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> situations occurring, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Kingmaker</style> possibilities work against <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> and therefore against <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> as well.
